{{main|Cannon in the Middle Ages}} [[File:SiegeOfOrleans1429.jpg|thumb|Depiction of artillery in a 1490s illustration of the [[Siege of Orleans]] of 1429.]] The '''artillery of France in the Middle Ages''' begins only with the fourteenth century, a century in which appears for the first time in Europe a depiction of a [[cannon]], in [[Walter de Milemete]]'s 1326 ''De Nobilitatibus sapientii et prudentiis regum'', and in which start to appear small rudimentary weapons such as the [[pot-de-fer]] or the portable [[bâton à feu]]. At this early stage, cannon would fire either stone balls or metal pellets.<ref name="Wagner34">John A. Wagner, ''Encyclopedia of the Hundred Years War'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=uVZ893wOWgoC&pg=PA34 p.34]</ref>
==14th-century developments== [[File:Rempart.gabionnades.et.palis.png|thumb|[[Eugène Viollet-Le-Duc]]'s impression of late medieval artillery in action (1856)]] The 14th century saw a considerable development of the new weapons in France and in Western Europe in general, especially with the outbreak of the [[Hundred Years' War]] (1337–1453).
Cannons were soon used at sea, with ships being used as firing platform. Small guns projecting [[Quarrel (projectile)|quarrel]]s or lead pellets were used at the 1340 [[Battle of Sluys]], and in the [[Siege of Tournai (1340)|French defense of Tournai]] in August 1340.<ref name="Wagner34" />
[[Edward III of England|Edward III]] used similar weapons at the [[Battle of Crécy]] in 1346, and in the [[Siege of Calais (1346)|Siege of Calais]] in 1347.<ref name="Wagner34" /> "Ribaldis" were first mentioned in the English Privy Wardrobe accounts during preparations for the [[Battle of Crécy]] between 1345 and 1346.
Cannons evolved considerably towards the end of the century with the collapse of the [[Treaty of Bretigny]] and the resumption of the war in 1369. Until 1370, cannons were essentially small weapons of 10 to 20 kg (20 to 40 lbs), made of [[brass]] or [[copper]]. After that point, larger guns appeared, made of [[wrought iron]] or [[cast iron]].<ref name="Wagner34" /> During the 1375 siege of [[Saint-Sauveur-le-Vicomte]], French troops successfully breached the walls of the fortress with guns weighing over 1 ton, and firing 50 kg stone balls. The English trailed behind French developments in the area and only had a few such weapons before 1400.<ref name="Wagner34" />
By the end of the century, new firearm types appeared, such as a variety of [[hand guns]], small [[Mortar (weapon)|mortars]] and [[ribaudequin]]s.<ref name="Wagner34" /> These complemented, but did not replace, heavier artillery.
<gallery widths="200px" perrow="3"> File:Arrow fireing cannon1.jpg|Reconstitution of a [[pot-de-fer]], described in 1326 by [[Walter de Milemete]]. File:Baton a feu.jpg|[[Bâton à feu]], or hand [[Bombard (weapon)|bombard]] (1380). [[Musée de l'Armée]]. File:HandBombardWesternEurope1390-1400.jpg|A ''bâton à feu'' with its wooden pole, France, 1390-1400. </gallery>
==15th-century developments== [[File:Coulevriniers.jpg|thumb|left|15th-century culveriners.]] By the early 15th century, both armies had a wide variety of gunpowder weapons.<ref name="Wagner34" /> Large guns were developed, known as [[bombard (weapon)|bombard]]s (French ''bombardes''), weighing up to 3 tonnes and firing stone balls of up to 150 kg (300 lbs), which seem to have been more prevalent among the French than among the English until 1420.<ref name="Wagner34" /> Such bombards were often made by welding bars of wrought iron together and holding them inside circular [[bracelet]]s, a process known as ''"à tonoille"'', similar to that involving the manufacture of wine barrels (''tonneaux'').<ref>[[Musée de l'Armée]] notice</ref>
''[[Veuglaires]]'' (English "fowlers") were developed, up to 2 meters (8 feet) long, and weighing from 150 kg to several tonnes, while the ''[[crapaudins]]'' or ''crapaudaux'' were shorter (4 to 8 feet) and lighter than the ''veuglaires''.<ref name="Wagner34" />
The first Western image of a battle with cannon goes back to the [[Siege of Orleans]] in 1429, in which both the English and the French side are depicted with firearms. French cannon killed the English commander [[Thomas Montacute, 4th Earl of Salisbury|Thomas Montagu]] in 1428.<ref name="Wagner35">John A. Wagner, ''Encyclopedia of the Hundred Years War'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=uVZ893wOWgoC&pg=PA35 p.35]</ref> [[Joan of Arc]] used cannon effectively during the Loire campaign in 1429.<ref name="Wagner35" />
[[File:Veuglaire powder box caliber 130 length 107 early 15th century La Fere.jpg|thumb|Powder chamber of a ''[[Veuglaire]]'', caliber 130mm, length 1.07m, wrought iron, early 15th century, [[La Fère]].]]
Portable [[hand cannons]], the ancestors of modern [[firearms]], continued to be used on a wide scale, sometimes even by mounted soldiers. Small portable arms were also developed such as ''[[Gunpowder#Serpentine|serpentines]]'' and ''[[couleuvrines]]''.<ref name="Wagner34" /> They were not able, however, to replace the widespread [[longbow]]s or [[crossbow]]s during the Hundred Years' War.<ref name="Wagner34" /> In contrast, cannon took on a major role in [[siege warfare]], where they came to replace traditional wooden [[siege engine]]s of the types used since [[ancient history|antiquity]].<ref name="Wagner34" />
From the 1430s, the artillery of [[Charles VII of France|Charles VII]] was managed by the Master Gunner [[Jean Bureau]]. Artillery was key to the French successes at [[Meaux]] (1439), [[Pontoise]] (1441), [[Caen]] and during the Norman Campaign (1449–1450).<ref name="Wagner35" /> French artillery was used with great efficiency at the 1453 [[Battle of Castillon]], in which grouped and entrenched cannons decimated the English army, killing the commander [[John Talbot, 1st Earl of Shrewsbury|John Talbot]].<ref name="Wagner35" />
Artillery also started to affect military architecture, leading to the development of lower, thicker walls in order to better resist the effect of cannonballs.<ref name="Wagner35" />
